data.title: Shire: Regina Pats going to ‘trust the process’ during rebuild
data.meta_description: The Pats announced several key hockey operations additions earlier this week as general manager Alan Millar continue to rebuild the club into a contender
data.text:
Article content

“Trust the process.”

Shire: Regina Pats going to ‘trust the process’ during rebuild Back to video

Those were the three words Regina Pats’ general manager Alan Millar ended Monday’s press conference with after announcing the entirety of his hockey operations department.

Since taking over as general manager from the retired John Paddock last off-season, Millar began the process of rebuilding the Pats, which included several big trades during the season and continued this week with the hiring of associate coach Ryan Smith and assistant general manager Dale Derkatch.

Article content

“I’m responsible for the big picture of the club and the big picture for me is winning a championship,” said Millar. “But there’s a process to that.”

In a season that saw the club finish last place in the Western Hockey League’s Eastern Conference with a 22-40-6 record — 17 points out of the playoffs — Millar traded away two of his top players including defenceman Parker Berge and forward Borya Valis. He was also able to trade Alexander Suzdalev, who was playing pro hockey in Sweden at the time of the deal.

What he got in return were several younger players and draft picks, who Millar hopes will become the future of the team.

“As a manager at this level, sometimes you have to understand you’re not good enough,” Millar said of last year’s mindset. “And you have to make the decisions around not being good enough and where do you want to go.

“We want to continue to build our team. We want to continue to get young players into our lineup. We want to continue to make sure we have the right development model around our young players and all our players getting better.

“Nobody here wants to just get by. Nobody wants to battle for the seventh or eighth playoff spot and just get in and lose in four or five games to a top team.

Article content

Article content

“We want to build it the right way. We want to be as competitive as we can and have that eye on, again, winning a championship.”

Having given head coach Brad Herauf and assistant coach Ken Schneider multiyear contract extensions, the Pats hired Smith, former head coach of the Spokane Chiefs, to serve as the club’s new associate head coach, replacing Evan McFeeters, who spent one year with the team as an assistant coach.

Millar also announced the hiring of Derkatch — the Pats’ all-time points leader — as the team’s new assistant general manager.

All the moves are part of a long-term vision for Millar, who joined the Pats after a stint with Hockey Canada which followed a decade spent with the Moose Jaw Warriors.

And while Regina won’t likely contend for a championship this season, the hope is that a few years down the road, they’ll be in the mix.

“The first step is to get competitive again and then the next step is to become a contender,” said Millar. “You can’t do one without the other.

“When I talk about being competitive, I talk about being a playoff team and growing from there.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

“But we want to be a competitive team this year. We want to be a playoff team and that’s what we’re working towards.”

While playoffs are still the goal for the 2024-25 WHL season, Millar will also be forced to make some tough decisions with some key assets on the team.

“Every decision we make, every player we sign, every draft pick we trade or acquire, every player we trade or acquire, we map it our through a four- or five-year plan,” said Millar. “There’s certainly a balance in terms of being competitive and at the same time as I mentioned, having that eye on the future.

“We’re going complement our group wisely (and) we’re going to complement our group reasonably. We’re going to have a vision and we’re going to have our eyes set on where we’re going to be two, three years down the road.”

With that vision — and a stable of hockey operations staff who believe the same — Millar will continue to put his stamp on the team this year in the hopes that one day that vision becomes a reality.

“There’s only one goal by this group,” he said. “And that’s to win a WHL championship and a Memorial Cup.

“And every decision we’ve made with this group and every decision we’re going to make moving forward is with that goal in mind.”
